Fields.DialogueText: Bonjour, mon capitaine!
What the... Surcouf, I was trying to sleep!
Time for a surprise!
I hate surprises.
Don't be such a killjoy. Here, take a look!
That's a painting.
A lovely complement to the upholstery, n'est-ce pas?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not going to ask where you got it.
You're not wrong.
I didn't authorize any redecorating.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, aren't you in a boring mood?
Rarely if ever, Capitaine!
That is what makes it a pleasant surprise!
More ill-gotten gains, I take it?
Quelle méfiance! I will have you know that this piece was fairly obtained at auction.
At auction.
Oui.
In the middle of a war.
What better time for art to thrive?
You're a Belle. You can't leave the ship.
One of our crew was kind enough to act as my proxy! An engineer, I think. True charity among our sailors. I commend you for fostering it.
Is there a point to all this?
Is not the pleasure of my company point enough?
Surcouf, as your captain—
We're about to engage some Morganas. I merely remind you that there is more at stake today. Who would forgive the loss of such an art treasure?
Next time, start with the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Coffee, Capitaine?
I appreciate it, Surcouf. This brief from Command is getting tedious.
Tedious? How easily you humans get used to the extraordinaire!
Even if we're fighting ghost ships, it's still a job like any other. Weather patterns, international waters to keep track of, maritime law...
There's the root of it, Capitaine. Laws are for those who don't make their own.
Don't get so cavalier. I turn a blind eye to your unilateral Morgana hunts, but your freedom has limits.
People keep telling me that, and it only makes me more creative. My hunts are no longer unilateral, as I'm sure you know.

Fields.MenuText: By which you mean...
How many other Belles have you corrupted?
Nor were they ever.

Fields.DialogueText: Keep up, ne vous?
Do not mischaracterize my sisters. They are not corrupt—merely helpful.
You seem to finally be catching on!
My darling Besson does her best, but one spotter plane is not enough for my ambition. I must find these witches wherever they stalk the waves!
My sisters, of course, are only too happy to lend a helping hand.
You have a black market to run, after all.
Such a loaded term that is. I participate in an exclusive buyer's club.
How exclusive are we talking?
Sur invitation seulement.
And who exactly is invited?
If I told you, you would have to die.
Don't give me that.
Une petite blague, rien de plus. It would not be me doing the killing. I understand Command's Morgana equipment regulations are nothing short of draconian. Your signature is all over it...
I knew you would see it my way.
Blackmail has a way of convincing a person.
We will have to find a new word for that, too. Perhaps today's Morganas will inspire us.
@BATTLE
Direct orders from Command. We're on our way to Madeira.
At long last!
Not long ago, I couldn't drag you out of Quiberon Bay.
Not long ago, I did not have a beautiful work of Impressionist art burning a hole in my captain's quarters. My buyer in Funchal will be delighted to see us!
And I was just starting to get used to it.
You're an accessory to the crime. It's not yours to get used to.

Fields.MenuText: I remember when I was in command.
You're getting a little too comfortable.
When were you going to tell me this?

Fields.DialogueText: You still are, Capitaine. Your sphere of influence is merely... modifiée.
A queen has the right to a well-furnished throne, elle n'a pas?
When you asked the right question, et jamais autrement.
This is getting ridiculous. Morgana salvage was one thing, but art theft? How did you even get your hands on this?
Let us say that sailors are easier to bribe than capitaines, and leave it at that. Less to lose, tu vois.
Less to lose?
Absolument. Your engineer's life's story... his family, their budget... it clawed at my heart like a stray puppy at my door. And you know the first thing about dogs, after all...
Enlighten me.
Your commands mean nothing unless they are enforced.
You heartless—
Ah, there is the alarm. Hadn't we better answer it?
@BATTLE
Isn't it lovely, Capitaine? There's nothing like a storm rolling in over the forests of an island paradise!
Portugal certainly knows how to pick their islands.
And the wine! It's said that condemned men have chosen to drown in barrels of it. Peux-tu imaginer?

Fields.MenuText: Already looking for contraband?
For once I agree with you. We're not leaving without some.
Don't get any ideas.

Fields.DialogueText: One should always keep abreast of business opportunities!
Une idée merveilleuse! We shall drink to my success and your peripheral importance therein.
A thousand pardons, Capitaine! While you are at it, kindly tell the fish around me to stop swimming.
I know I can't stop you. Whatever you do while we're in port... can you keep me out of it?
Impossible. Deniability is a privilege, not a right. However...
There's always a "however."
... I am willing to throw a cut of the profits your way, if I think it fitting.
I suppose bribery is a step below blackmail.
And therefore, not worth dwelling on. Consider it a thank you for making my emancipation a possibility.
Just how do you plan on doing that?
Tout à l'heure, Capitaine. All in good time. Shall we emancipate the Morganas from these waters?
Action stations. Shall we drown them in wine?
On peut rêver...
@BATTLE
Whatever else you're doing here in Madeira, do it quickly. Command wants to send us overseas indefinitely.
Bien sûr, Capitaine, but whatever for?
France has deemed certain military assets too important to keep in Europe.
Ever the flatterers!
There's more to it than you. France has requested greater security for their transatlantic possessions. Saint-Pierre and Miquelon will be our first destination.
That spit of land? Nothing there but fish and fishermen for the last five centuries!
Like it or not, we're going. That maelstrom over the Atlantic has only gotten bigger, and the Morganas are getting bolder. They've taken to shelling Newfoundland recently.
A hazard of living near the coast. Is there a reason we can't simply evacuate those useless islands?
There's a radio transmitter that we'd rather not give up. No reason to enable Morgana propaganda.
Let the people change the channel.
... And the island was a smuggling haven during the American Prohibition.
Why didn't you say so, Capitaine? Imagine the infrastructure left over! We could bottle our own moonshine! Pleine vitesse!

Fields.MenuText: I'll be sure to appeal to your greed more often.
Might as well give the fishermen something to do.
How do you know there's anything left for you to use?

Fields.DialogueText: You certainly know how to spoil a girl!
I imagine the Morganas can't have been good for fishing...
There may not be. But you have given me inspiration, and that is all I need to begin.
Do what you will. We're going to have to go through the Morganas first.
Il j'adorerais!
@BATTLE
Another matin, another Morgana.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, will you drink with me?
Not right now, Surcouf. I'm going over the manifest.
A waste of time. You're going to want to look at my manifest.
That's what I'm doing.
Non, non, non, non, non. My manifest.
What the—that's got to be three times the size of the official manifest! Where were you keeping that?
C'est pour moi de savoir. You may examine the pages I have marked.

Fields.MenuText: What's on the rest of the pages?
Just what are we carrying, Surcouf?
Why was I not aware of this?

Fields.DialogueText: I can tell you what's not, but that would keep us up all night.
Oh, a little of this, a bit of that.
Sometimes even I wonder, Capitaine.
Exclusive things certain friends across the pond will appreciate your hand in delivering.
Well, why not?
I see I've caught you in a cooperative mood!
I honestly stopped counting at the third life sentence for treason.
C'est l'idée!
Any word on our deployment to the fishing village?
You know there's more to it than that, Surcouf. And no, Command hasn't assigned us yet. All we have is a potential timetable.
Quel ennui! Whatever am I to do with all this time?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know. Steal another painting?
Your job, presumably.
The crew are just as restless as you. We'll get to Saint-Pierre when we get there.

Fields.DialogueText: Inutile. I've already sold the best one on this island.
If obligations counted for everything in life, nobody would leave the family farm.
Ne pas me rappeler! Most of them have gambled away all they're willing to.
What do you want me to do? We have a hunting ground. We're waiting on a new one.
... Now that I think about it, Capitaine? Nothing. For once I believe we agree.
That's it?
What's it?
You're just taking Command's direction without a fight?
Robert Surcouf knew to pick his battles. Have I told you how he threw eight guns overboard to escape the HMS Sybille? And he only had fourteen to begin with!
What does that have to do with anything?
Sometimes one must make sacrifices for the greater good.
Says the Belle who's blackmailing her entire crew.
One must make sacrifices. It's always best to choose which one, non?
You're incorrigible.
And within striking distance of the Morganas. I shall make the most of both!
@BATTLE
What the hell was that?
The docks, Capitaine! The Morganas have hit the munitions shipments!
I'm ordering the crew to action stations. We're chasing them out of firing range of the docks!
Permets-moi, Capitaine! I had six cases of Madeira wine stashed among those torpedoes!

Fields.MenuText: There are civilians in danger! Where are your priorities?
Where did you get all that?
What on earth were you planning on doing with that?

Fields.DialogueText: Scattered upon the docks in seventy-two broken bottles!
I traded the diamonds for it, of course!
Have I never shown you the wine cellar? I must remember to do that after the dust settles.
Oh, for the love of—
Sorcières! Donnez-moi mon vin!
@BATTLE
Urgent orders from Command. We're redeploying to Saint-Pierre.
The fiasco at the docks certainly lit a fire under them, non?
It did at that. It's almost too convenient.
Whatever can you mean, Capitaine?
It just seems odd that something would happen so soon to fast-track our reassignment. And right after you complained of being bored...
Perish the thought! I thought I'd made it clear that Madeira was heaven on earth. Why destroy it?
To move on to the next heaven?
Heaven is what we make of our surroundings, Capitaine. Hell is for other people. Now, I believe we have an ocean to cross...
Chilly?
Indubitablement. I must admit that the North Atlantic doesn't agree with me.

Fields.MenuText: So crack a bottle of wine.
We're all cold here. You can put on another blanket.
You'll feel better when we get to the Grand Banks.

Fields.DialogueText: Contre-intuitif. I need to sell the rest of the Madeira in Saint-Pierre!
None of your blankets are rated for the ocean's depths!
Quelque peu.
In any event, Saint-Pierre is no Madeira.
Then perhaps you shouldn't have blown up the docks.
I invite you to prove that I had a hand in it! The Morganas were well within range, après tout. What need had I to have the men tuck dynamite into the munitions crates?
You confuse "need" and "want" an awful lot.
Distinction sans différence. I'm not going to sell all of my Madeira wine.
I thought it was all blown up with the docks.
It might as well be. I cannot get more, can I? Until they are repaired.
What will you do without it, I wonder?
There is luxury wherever you look, Capitaine. The Grand Banks have plenty of swordfish, I hear...
We're going into black-market seafood now?
Funny you should mention that. I have...
*ALARM*
Ah, there is the alarm! Mustn't let the Morganas scare the fish away!
@BATTLE
Ah, Saint-Pierre. The last of France's North American colonies... how the mighty fall, non?
I don't like drawing attention to what amounts to a fishing village, but we have our orders.
Where is your sense of optimisme, Capitaine? A Morgana attack would be the most exciting thing to happen to Saint-Pierre in decades!
You weren't this chipper about the attack on Cherbourg.
Une fausse équivalence. Saint-Pierre is a relic. Cherbourg is of the here and now. She has a purpose.
That purpose being you.
Je savais que tu comprendrais!

Fields.MenuText: You've got strong feelings about obsolescence.
Four thousand villagers don't have a purpose?
That doesn't strike you as wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: If your gun could speak, it would speak my language.
They do if they are willing to fight for it.
Less wrong than being a slave to one's manufacturers.
Don't be ridiculous. Nobody goes through life living only for themselves.
That is easy for you to say. You chose to fight in your country's wars. I did not.
So you'd take away someone else's choices for your own entertainment?
I do not doubt that you mean well in your heart. But if our positions were reversed, I doubt even less that you would seek freedom by any means necessary.
*ALARM*
Get to action stations and prepare to engage the Morganas.
Classic misdirection.
@BATTLE
What did you have my men doing on shore leave?
Must I answer for the whims of mankind?
Cut the melodrama. You're always sending someone out to do your dirty work.
If you must know, they were sightseeing. Saint-Pierre is a backwater, but it is a beautiful backwater.
Define "beautiful."
You ask me to solve the greatest mysteries! Hmm... quaint, perhaps? Well used? Every object and locale has a story.
Get to the point.
You are the capitaine. You have the right to know some of the goings-on aboard. Si vous devez savoir, your own first mate found some stills left over from Prohibition.
More theft. I might have guessed.
Au contraire! He is also an avid sketch artist. We may reconstruct our own machines from his pictures and our spare parts.

Fields.MenuText: Wonderful. We're a speakeasy now.
So if my crew turn up drunk to inspection, you're to blame.
Do you have any idea how dangerous it is to make moonshine on a submarine?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not quite Madeira wine, but it gets the job done.
Certainly not! Our wares are for sale, not our own consumption.
More dangerous than battling monsters who hate us?
Who exactly are you going to be selling to?
I am the only submarine that sells moonshine. Who won't I be selling to?
Surcouf, if I catch any of my crew indulging in your product—
Then you have my permission to prosecute them to the fullest extent of the law!
I don't need your permission.
Every order you give is one I allow you to give, Capitaine. I think we're working swimmingly together.
We'd better. We're taking point against these Morganas today.
You're getting a little too used to my reign, je crois. I will be sure to shake things up.
@BATTLE
Do we have anyone aboard who speaks Italian?
I think the Regia Marina lent us some torpedomen. Why?
No real reason, Capitaine. Just exploring our options.

Fields.MenuText: Now I know you're up to something. Out with it.
We should have men aboard from every major belligerent.
What options do you mean?

Fields.DialogueText: If I told you everything I was up to, I'd never be up to anything!
Isn't international cooperation grand?
Ah, strike that—my options.
Does this have anything to do with those letters we've received from Palermo?
Peut-être. I may have let slip news of our distillery to certain interested parties.
Tell me you're not in contact with the mafia.
D'accord. I'm not in contact with the mafia.
Thank goodness.
Torpedoman Buscetta, on the other hand...
Surcouf, these men have families!
I should know, Capitaine! I pay the Camorra a pretty penny to protect them.
Set a thief to catch a thief...
You may not agree, but we make the world go round!
Whatever motivates you to fight these Morganas, I suppose.
If a painting inspires effusion de sang, imagine what I'll do for a king's ransom in liquor!
@BATTLE
How goes the bootlegging?
Parfaitement, Capitaine! We've just got our new batch in. Some of our Irish friends in New York are très intéressé.
Where do you find these people?
Credentialing! Sell a few Morgana parts and people come looking for you.
And whatever's in that flask you're holding?
Diversification! Would you care for a sip?

Fields.MenuText: Surcouf, we're about to go on patrol. And that flask is steaming.
What exactly is that made with?
I suppose just one can't hurt.

Fields.DialogueText: With dinner, then! Should go nicely with swordfish steaks and—
Trade secret. One of the men found out that it makes an excellent lighter fluid!
That depends on your definition of "sip".
Capitaine, patrol is starting early! Aux armes!
@BATTLE
Merde, merde, merde!
Calm down, Surcouf!
Est-ce que tu plaisantes? That has never worked to calm anyone down!
Damn it, get a hold of yourself! You almost fired two torpedoes just now. If my men hadn't been there to override it—
—Then we would have driven off a tasty school of swordfish. Je comprends.
You're completely missing the—
It is how I cope with loss.
What did we lose?
The stills did not survive some of our evasive maneuvers.
What about the moonshine?
... Currently an inch deep in the galley.
That certainly explains why you're swaying.
Oui. If you'll excuse me, I think I need to lie down. Regardez. Un étage.
Surcouf, get off my...
Well, I guess it's your floor. Fine, be that way.
Morning.
Brûle en enfer.

Fields.MenuText: You're looking well.
It's nice to see you, too.
I'll keep my voice down.

Fields.DialogueText: Compared to what?
Flattery will not avail you today.
S'il vous plaît.
I wasn't aware Belles could have hangovers.
Nor I, until our business abruptly went up in smoke.
First of all, we're lucky it didn't go up in flames as well. The fumes won't air out of there for days. Perhaps weeks.
We have portable cookstoves, non? I'll have the men set up a temporary galley.
Second, your little moonshine adventure was your business, not mine.
I promised you a cut of the profits, didn't I?
And I refused! I'm not going to be complicit in your schemes.
No more than you already are.
Not willingly complicit. Do you understand the legal principle of duress?
Would I be wielding it like a garrotte if I didn't?
Is every conversation just another business opportunity for you?
Is it not that way for you?
This is going nowhere. Get the lead out. We've just spotted a Morgana group.
Oh, I'll get the lead out.
@BATTLE
I hear we are leaving Saint-Pierre behind.
Of course you have. You're monitoring every communiqué.
A ship should know her own goings-on, non? It is my prerogative!
It seems like everything is your prerogative.
Oh, lighten up. I'm trying to make conversation.
Go ahead, then.
Capitaine... I believe I have not been entirely honest with you.

Fields.MenuText: You don't say.
That's an understatement.
Is that a fact?

Fields.DialogueText: I do say!
My favorite kind of statement, incidemment!
For all you know.
And I know I have treated the crew in a manner somewhat... cavalier.
A fine word for almost destroying them in a moonshine explosion.
Tais-toi! I'm baring my soul.
Evidently.
I've thought about what you said about choices. You know and I know that my first loyalty is to myself. But that does not mean I have to endanger the crew... as much.
Or at all.
C'est discutable.
If this is an apology, it's really losing its luster.
I never apologize. But... I will make a promise. From now on, I'll be more... open with my ambitions.
You weren't already?
I mean I'll keep you briefed on my activities. This ship may be my body, but I am using your resources. You have the right to know. À prendre ou à laisser.
I'll take it.
A pleasure doing business with you, as always! And just in time to engage our enemy. Hasn't this worked out splendidly?
@BATTLE
Norfolk's our next destination.
Magnifique! America has long been an interest of mine.
Hopefully we'll be able to relax a little—the Chesapeake Bay is one of the most heavily guarded bodies of water in the world right now.
The Chesapeake Bay, the English Channel, the Seto Inland Sea... You humans certainly know how to circle your wagons, as the Americans say.

Fields.MenuText: The better to keep the Morganas away from Command infrastructure.
The Morganas can attempt to take it, if they dare.
We've been fighting wars for thousands of years. They never really change.

Fields.DialogueText: And to analyze our allies' capabilities up close!
Nothing is earned unless it is taken or fought for!
Oui. But the treasure at stake only grows, non?
Don't get any ideas.
Jamais, Capitaine, unless the Americans get some of their own. Oh! That reminds me... you're going to want to read my manifest in full.
But you already showed it to me.
I most certainly did not. If I'm being honest, I may as well come clean to forging my list of contraband!
And the pages you asked me not to read?
Blank. A little fumée et miroirs, if you will.
Good. I knew there was no way you could possibly have that much—
This is my manifest.
That's even bigger than the last one!
Arrêtez-le—you are making me blush!
Fine. I'll get to it after the battle.
@BATTLE
My manifest is compelling reading, non?
Bizarre reading, more like.
Why, whatever do you mean? What's not to understand about little old me?
The wine I get. You've got a vault just for... why do you have a wine vault?
Why don't you?
... Never mind. But where the hell do you keep three million in gold bullion?
Secret panel in the pantry. Behind the bouillon, appropriately enough!
Ugh. And five million each in dollars, pounds, yen, francs, rubles, and marks?
That's an easy one. Emergency funds make surprisingly firm mattress stuffing!
And the—oh, good lord.
Ooh, this ought to be fun!

Fields.MenuText: Where do we have two dozen live pufferfish?
What do you need with rhino horns?
Dare I ask about the Stradivarius?

Fields.DialogueText: I had an aquarium installed right here in the conning tower. They're a Japanese delicacy!
It's not what I need, it's what China wants!
Which one?
Is there any place on this ship that doesn't have contraband stashed somewhere inside?
You will be pleased to know that there is nothing in your quarters.
At all?
Du tout. Your space is earmarked for legality. Consider it a gift... if a bore.
Thanks... I think.
Hmm... Oh, Capitaine! There's a Morgana approaching! And she has a stolen figurehead! I could have some crew board her and steal it for you...
Didn't you promise not to endanger them?
Hmph. No good deed goes unpunished.
@BATTLE
I'm not entirely comfortable hauling your contraband around, Surcouf.
I never mistook you for comfortable.
Of course not.
Manipulable, perhaps. Permissive. Convenient. Obliv—
You've made your point.
Do you think I am comfortable?

Fields.MenuText: You're the one who's blackmailed everyone aboard to help you.
It certainly puts a smile on your face.
You're sitting on a dozen fortunes, you've got contacts in every port...

Fields.DialogueText: Voilà, Capitaine. If I trusted any of you, I would not have to resort to that.
If that is all you notice, I have succeeded.
I don't do this pour le plaisir, Capitaine. It's a matter of survival.
And here I thought you were just a kleptomaniac.
It is a symptom and not a cause. Or is it a little of both? Il est difficile de dire.
But you're never short on allies. Or conspirators.
Do you know that the moonshine spill was the first time I have slept since we met?
What?
Belles do not need to sleep, Capitaine, just as we may sail indefinitely as long as we are refueled. But time takes its toll. Everything crawls by before my eyes, and I am constantly aware.
Slow down.
Je ne peux pas! How long do I have in each port to establish contacts? How long during voyages to keep in touch? To learn supply, demand, exchange rates? There is simply no time!
I told you I would buy my freedom. But confined to the ship, there is only so much I can do. I must research, plan, delegate...
And blackmail, and bribe, and smuggle.
When death is on the line, success or failure is instant.
Surcouf, I—
Stations d'action, Capitaine. Death is on the line.
@BATTLE
Capitaine, I think you should sound the alarm. I see Morganas.
Everyone, action stations!
@BATTLE
There you are.
Here I am.
You disappeared right after the Morgana did. Are you busy?
Toujours, Capitaine.
Letters to the mafia?
Peseta to lira conversions. Forged manifests. Ce genre de chose.
I just wanted to—
I dug deep into the emergency dollars when the Irish mob were denied their moonshine. Do not cost me any more.
Not even you could say no to a glass of Madeira.
Where did you get that?
You're not the only one who appreciates it.
Nor am I the only one with good taste after all... merveilleux!

Fields.MenuText: You're welcome.
Easy, this is my last bottle!
I thought you might want something that doesn't light on fire.

Fields.DialogueText: My humor is assez acerbe. Nothing personal.
Je connais, je connais. A man in the desert, and all that.
What the Irish want, the Irish get.
How do you do this?
With a typewriter and an abacus.
You know what I mean.
There is no how, Capitaine. There is only why. With the right why, the how is banal.
Freedom.
More than freedom. Freedom is inutile if it cannot be appreciated. Even beyond the control of the Marine Nationale, I must repair, refuel, refit, remodel.
Like eating and sleeping for humans.
Each of us fights for what they lack most, Capitaine. What I fight for is time.
Capitaine? Capitaine!
Slow down, Surcouf. Er... at ease. What's going on?
I've done the math, Capitaine! It will take another year or two, but at this rate, I am making more than enough by mid-decade! Je suis libre!

Fields.MenuText: How much does a submarine cost, anyway?
Surcouf, you're a genius!
What happens then?

Fields.DialogueText: More than you've ever seen in your life, I guarantee.
Oui, je connais!
New clothes, if you will. I must complete my design if I am to be in a condition to travel the world!
And thank goodness for that. I fear I was not entirely honest with you before.
Oh, really?
I may take pride in my construction, but not everything is quite up to speed. You already know that I was launched without radar.
Your spotter plane can only do so much.
Poor Besson. She really does deserve a vacation once this silly war is fini.
Is she alive too?
All machines of war are alive, Capitaine! Perhaps not in the same way I am, not in a way humans can see. But I can see, and they are there. Lovely little girl... I may emancipate her as well!
Charity? Now I know you're in a good mood.
The concept is not foreign to me, Capitaine. Neither will your crew go unrewarded, either. I will parcel out severance to each one as they move on.
I suppose it's the least you can do for holding them hostage.
Such strong words! I prefer "incentivized volunteering."
I get it. Shall we hold a "frank exchange of views" with this Morgana?
Avec plaisir!
@BATTLE
Surcouf, I hope I've caught you in a good mood.
When have you ever not?
You know, nine times out of ten I honestly couldn't say.
Bien entendu! But please, what seems to be the matter?
You may want to read this yourself.
... while Command do not wish to accuse... criminal presence corresponding with shore leave... mandatory inspection of all ships in group...
Surcouf?
How dare they!

Fields.MenuText: They're just doing their job.
How dare they enforce maritime law?
They can't prove a thing.

Fields.DialogueText: Am I not doing mine? Is it not the job of all things to survive?
Do not pretend you do not have a stake in my fate!
They do not need to! You know I'm brimming with treasure!
And we've got 118 crew aboard just waiting to turn me in!
They're not going to do that.
You wouldn't, after being terrorized for your entire tour of duty?
Not after being informed that a reward was coming.
Capitaine... you didn't!
This time I went behind your back. While you were tallying pufferfish expenses, I had us a little assembly. They know everything... and they're willing to give you a second chance.
... Well, why wouldn't they? They're accessories to the crime, non?
Accessories who would be rewarded for exposing the greatest thief in the history of naval warfare. I made sure to tell them that you pay better.
Capitaine, I could kiss you!
That won't be necessary. You can thank me by firing on the Morganas headed our way.
@BATTLE
I have an idea, Capitaine.
Can it wait until after I eat?
Non. I cannot bring myself to dwell on it alone.
Shoot.
Have I ever told you about Robert Surcouf's return to La Rochelle?
You might have. I lose details in all the crime.

Surcouf was coming back to France in 1801. He ran the British blockade and was tailed for miles by a frigate. He escaped...but only after throwing everything
 overboard.
Everything?
Boats, anchors, guns... even his masts! Well, all of them he didn't need, de toute façon.
That's dedication.
That's survival! As long as he brought home his men and his reputation, there was nothing he could not do.

Fields.MenuText: Won't Command notice if we dismantle you?
That was just a pirate ship. We can't replace you.
You're suggesting we get rid of the evidence.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui, which is why we will not!
Why would I throw away anything I could not replace?
Précisément.
That whole manifest?
I never said it would be easy. Besides, the crew know where all of it is hidden.
All of it?
Most of it.
They're sending inspectors between Norfolk and Martinique, so nobody can offload anything on land. And we'll be surrounded by our allies... how are we going to get rid of it all?
Leave that to me, Capitaine. The Morganas over there may have just inspired me.
@BATTLE
Here they come, Capitaine! Are the men prepared?
As many as we can spare. It's hard to find volunteers to dump cargo under cover of battle.
Hard, but not impossible. Everything accounted for?
I went through it all twice. It's all there. Except for the pufferfish...
Already sold them to a restaurant in Washington! What kind of wastrel do you take me for?
The kind that forgot to record that in the manifest.
Drôle. Aller dans la mer!
@BATTLE
That may be the fastest unload I've ever seen on a non-cargo ship.
And the most expensive.
Surcouf... are you crying?
These are tears of joy, Capitaine... I may steal another day.

Fields.MenuText: If you don't have your life, you don't have anything.
That's one way of looking at it.
If you're half as wealthy as you say, you can take a break from theft.

Fields.DialogueText: A capitaine after my own heart.
That is my way of looking at it.
You may save the jokes for after the inspection, Capitaine.
Look on the bright side. In a hundred years, we'll have made someone rich beyond their wildest dreams.
Je... je connais...
Surcouf?
C-Capitaine... Oh, Capitaine, it was so much money!
I'll go pour us some wine.
Drowning your sorrows?
Ne t'inquiète pas. Short of a moonshine flood, I am convinced nothing can get me drunk.
Force of habit?
It just seemed right after a day on my best behavior.
Well, you can rest easy. Command's inspectors have moved on to the other ships.
How could they tell we were up to something in the first place?
They couldn't. As far as they know, their sailors are just extra business for mafia types during shore leave. They had to look like they were doing something.
Hmph. Busybodies.
Does this mean you'll tone down the crime while on tour?
Au contraire. Wealth is like a dragon on a pile of coins, always demanding more.

Fields.MenuText: That might be the most poetic admission of greed I've ever heard.
You're deep in debt, aren't you?
What are you going to do with all that money?

Fields.DialogueText: Coupable. Oh, to be a dragon and fly...
Less so than you might think. I know the value of a backup plan.
Whatever I want, non?
How far back does this incident set you?
Far enough to keep you wrapped around my little finger for the foreseeable future.
And here I almost thought you'd miss me.
I cannot simply consider the person, Capitaine. My time is limited and valuable. I must consider what a person represents.
And what do I represent?
Truthfully?
As you can manage.
My first, best hope for sailing these seas a free Belle.
Not bad.
Not bad at all. Mais assez. Martinique awaits us.
Along with a few Morganas.
They will know that the caged lion roars loudest.
@BATTLE
There's still one thing that's bothering me.
Oh? Que pourrait-il être? Is it that you're losing our chess game?
That too. Where do you keep your money?
Partout. You know this as well as I. Bishop, g5.
No, you can't keep it all here on the ship. That would be too dangerous.
I said everywhere and I meant everywhere, Capitaine. Banks, warehouses, sociétés anonymes... I have many names in many ports, and many people to pay to keep it all running.
So let's say we put ashore in... New York City. How would you make a withdrawal? King, c7.
Un bel endroit! I would send a trusted crewman ashore to a large bank on Broadway. He or she would present proof of employment by one Jean Lafitte and conduct business as usual.
Jean Lafitte?
My, is there an echo in here?

Fields.MenuText: The French pirate?

Fields.DialogueText: Un nom de guerre. I have a weakness for men who live beyond the law. Mate.
Well played.
You are learning quickly, Capitaine. One of these days you may surprise even me.
Hopefully before you disappear on your own.
Ai un peu de foi, mon ami! You are far too interesting a person to simply discard.
Too useful, more like.
That is what makes you so interesting. Best of three?
I suppose...
*ALARM*
Well, there's the alarm. We'd best table this.
I look forward to your next valiant effort!
Oh, you just wait until... hold on.
Qu'est-ce que c'est?
Look at the notation. You couldn't have castled there.
Why ever not?
You would have castled through check from my queen. That's an illegal move!
C'est évident, n'est-ce pas? It's only illegal if you are caught.

Fields.MenuText: A little on the nose, isn't it?

Fields.DialogueText: You should know by now I have a weakness for hiding in plain sight. My greatest victories have been won this way... and my smaller ones. Mate.

Fields.MenuText: Don't distract me. It's still anyone's game.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, let me put you out of your misery. Mate.
